-   I can modify my colors to be accessible to anyone's eyes

```{r}
#| label: dvs-2-ex-2

# Lab 8, Q3
# RColorBrewer palette used in style_plot() to produce an accessible, cohesive palette
# Both shape and color utilized in pretty_scatter() to be color blind friendly

# helper function for building labels
labelize <- function(var){
  enquo(var) |>
  as_label() |>
  str_replace_all(pattern = "_", 
                  replacement = " ") |>
  str_to_title()
}

# create a "pretty" scatterplot :)
pretty_scatter <- function(df, x, y, cat){
  title_lab = englue("Scatterplot of {{x}} and {{y}} by {{cat}}") |>
              str_replace_all(pattern = "_", 
                              replacement = " ") |>
              str_to_title()
  x_lab = labelize({{x}})
  y_lab = labelize({{y}})
  color_lab = labelize({{cat}})
  
  df |>
    ggplot(mapping = aes(x = {{x}}, 
                         y = {{y}}, 
                         color = {{cat}},
                         shape = {{cat}})) +
      geom_point() +
      labs(
        title = title_lab,
        x = x_lab,
        y = y_lab,
        color = color_lab
           ) +
      guides(
        color = guide_legend(title = color_lab),
        shape = guide_legend(title = color_lab)
      ) 
}

style_plot <- function(plot, 
                       aesthetic = "fill", 
                       theme_fn = theme_bw(), 
                       palette = RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(8, "Accent")) {
  
  if (aesthetic == "fill") {
      plot + 
      scale_fill_manual(values = palette) +
      theme_fn +
      theme(
        plot.title = element_text(face = "bold")
      )
  } else if (aesthetic == "color") {
      plot + 
      scale_color_manual(values = palette) +
      theme_fn +
      theme(
        plot.title = element_text(face = "bold")
      )
  } else {
    stop("Not a valid color aesthetic. Choose 'fill' or 'color'.")
  }
}

penguins |>
  pretty_scatter(x = flipper_length_mm, 
                 y = body_mass_g, 
                 cat = species) |>
  style_plot(theme_fn = theme_bw(), 
             palette = RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(2, "Set1"), 
             aesthetic = "color")
```

## Data Simulation & Statisical Models

**DSSM-1: I can simulate data from a *variety* of probability models.**

-   Example 1

```{r}
#| label: dsm-1-1

# Lab 10, Q4
# define slope and intercept parameters
intercept = 2
slope = 1

# generate x vector
x <- runif(n = 100, min = 0, max = 1)

# generate noise `ep` vector
ep <- rnorm(n = 100, mean = 0, sd = 1)


# generate outcome from population model
y = intercept + x*slope + ep

# create an "observed data" dataframe with only the x and y vectors
observed_data <- tibble(x = x, y = y)
```

-   Example 2

```{r}
#| label: dsm-1-2

# Lab 10, Q10
mycifun <- function(beta0, beta1, n) {
  sim_data <- tibble(
    x = runif(n, min = 0, max = 1),
    epsilon = rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = 1),
    y = beta0 + beta1 * x + epsilon
  )
  
  model <- lm(y ~ x, data = sim_data)
  
  estimates_df <- broom::tidy(
    model, 
    conf.int = TRUE, 
    conf.level = 0.95
  )
  
  final_result <- estimates_df |>
    filter(term == "x") |>
    mutate(
      true_beta1 = beta1,
      cover = ifelse(
        (true_beta1 >= conf.low) & (true_beta1 <= conf.high),
        1,
        0
      )
    ) |>
    select(
      slope_estimate = estimate,
      lower_bound_ci = conf.low,
      upper_bound_ci = conf.high,
      is_covered = cover
    )
  
  return(final_result)
}

set.seed(123)
ci_dat <- map(.x = 1:1000,
              .f = ~mycifun(beta0 = 3, beta1 = .5, n = 100)
              )
```
